title: VFLUX - Vertical Fluid Heat Transfer Solver
summary: "VFLUX is a program that calculates one-dimensional vertical fluid flow (seepage flux) through saturated porous media, using heat transport equations. It uses temperature time series data measured by multiple temperature sensors in a vertical profile in order to calculate flux at specific times and depths. VFLUX is written as a MATLAB toolbox, a set of functions that run in the MATLAB environment." See 'Abstract': https://www.hydroshare.org/resource/4df337867d314620bd87b27c6732e6fe/ Model Name (Name of the model, including acronyms): VFLUX - Vertical Fluid Heat Transfer Solver (VFlu[H]X Solver) Model Version (Version of the model, (i.e., 2.0)): 2.0.0 Abstract (Description or summary of the model, including its purpose or goals and [...]
body:
"VFLUX is a program that calculates one-dimensional vertical fluid flow (seepage flux) through saturated porous media, using heat transport equations. It uses temperature time series data measured by multiple temperature sensors in a vertical profile in order to calculate flux at specific times and depths. VFLUX is written as a MATLAB toolbox, a set of functions that run in the MATLAB environment."

See 'Abstract': https://www.hydroshare.org/resource/4df337867d314620bd87b27c6732e6fe/

Model Name (Name of the model, including acronyms):

VFLUX - Vertical Fluid Heat Transfer Solver (VFlu[H]X Solver)

Model Version (Version of the model, (i.e., 2.0)):

2.0.0

Abstract (Description or summary of the model, including its purpose or goals and the type or formalism of the model (e.g., system dynamic, agent based model, machine learning), preferably accompanied by relevant keywords):

"VFLUX is a program that calculates one-dimensional vertical fluid flow (seepage flux) through saturated porous media, using heat transport equations. It uses temperature time series data measured by multiple temperature sensors in a vertical profile in order to calculate flux at specific times and depths. VFLUX is written as a MATLAB toolbox, a set of functions that run in the MATLAB environment."

See 'Abstract': https://www.hydroshare.org/resource/4df337867d314620bd87b27c6732e6fe/

Installation (Information on how to install the model so that it can be run (e.g., compilation and/or execution instructions)):

"The VFLUX program can be downloaded from the following web site: http://hydrology.syr.edu/ vflux. Copy the VFLUX toolbox folder (“vflux”) into a folder on the MATLAB search path, such as “My Documents\MATLAB” in Windows environments. Alternately, the location of the vflux folder can be added to the search path by typing addpath('C:\examplefolder\vflux') at the MATLAB command prompt. The MATLAB Signal Processing Toolbox must be installed, and the Captain Toolbox folder (“captain”) must also be added to the MATLAB search path. The Captain Toolbox can be downloaded from the following web site: http://www.es.lancs.ac.uk/cres/captain. If the Signal Processing Toolbox is not available, then a private ‘resample’ function may be used. This function can be downloaded along with VFLUX from the above web site, and must be copied to a folder called “private” within the VFLUX toolbox folder (“vflux”). The MATLAB Compiler Runtime (MCR) may also need to be installed; see the readme file included with the private resample function for more information. There are two functions in the toolbox that can be directly called by the user, VFLUXFormat (vfluxformat) and VFLUX (vflux). These functions are executed by typing their commands at the MATLAB command prompt, and can also be called by external functions or scripts, allowing them to be integrated into your custom workflow. VFLUXFormat is used to format and (optionally) synchronize multiple time series, where the data already exist in some form as variables in the MATLAB workspace. VFLUXFormat is called first, in order to prepare the data structure for use with VFLUX. VFLUX is then called to perform the resampling, filtering, and flux calculation routines on the formatted data structure. Descriptions of the inputs and options for the two functions are presented below, and can also be displayed in the MATLAB command window by typing help vfluxformat and help vflux at the command prompt."

See 'Content/vflux2.zip/vflux2/vflux2/VFLUX 2 Documentation/2. Installation': https://www.hydroshare.org/resource/4df337867d314620bd87b27c6732e6fe/

Version Updates (Changes since the last version (if the model is an update) including bug fixes, new features, or other substantive modifications, where appropriate):

"VFLUX 1.2.5: The original VFLUX code, with amplitude- and phase-based solutions to determine flux from temperature time series data, as well as signal processing methods, data visualization, sensitivity analysis, and Monte Carlo error analysis modules.

VFLUX 2.0.0: Includes all functionality of the original VFLUX, with the addition of solutions for the “combined” amplitude ratio and phase lag methods (Luce et al., 2013; McCallum et al., 2012). More information can be found in Irvine et al. (2015).

VFLUX requires the Captain Toolbox and the ‘resample’ function from the MATLAB Signal Processing Toolbox. The Captain Toolbox is available for free at http://www.lancs.ac.uk/staff/taylorcj/tdc/download.php. The Signal Processing toolbox is available from MathWorks at http://www.mathworks.com/products/signal/. If the Signal Processing Toolbox is not available to you, then an alternate function may be substituted (for more information, contact the authors)."

Input/Output and Variables (Key input parameters and their values and domain ranges and units (minimum input requirements for model operation and default values, where appropriate); control variables; Key output variables and domain ranges):

"Input Time Series Data VFLUX is designed to process temperature time series measured by multiple temperature sensors in a single streambed vertical profile (Figure 1). Table 1 contains example time series data collected from a vertical temperature profile. The time series data include a column of sample times, in days, and a column for each sensor of temperature values, in degrees Celsius, that were recorded at each sample time. The sample time values must be evenly-spaced in time and monotonically increasing throughout. For example, the data excerpted in Table 1 were sampled every 10 minutes without exception. Any gaps in time that occurred during data collection must be filled by interpolation. The time series data must be imported as array variables into the MATLAB workspace, either as individual column vectors or as a single large matrix. In the event that different sensors were sampled on different time schedules or for different lengths of time, then there must be a separate time series for each of the schedules. For example, if sensors 1, 2 and 3 were sampled on schedule A and sensors 4 and 5 on schedule B, then there would be two time columns, A and B, the first associated with temperature columns for sensors 1, 2 and 3, and the second with temperature columns for sensors 4 and 5. It is very important to note that VFLUX can only be used to analyze a raw dataset in which a strong periodic temperature signal exists (typically the diurnal, 24-hour signal driven by solar input) for a length of time long enough to filter the signal and discard the edge effects (see Flux Results section, below). This typically means at least one week of continuous time series data containing a 24-hour temperature signal."

See 'Content/vflux2.zip/vflux2/vflux2/VFLUX 2 Documentation/3. Input Time Series Data': https://www.hydroshare.org/resource/4df337867d314620bd87b27c6732e6fe/
